message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A 2-cm hypoechoic, homogeneous testicular mass with sharp margins and a single enlarged para-aortic lymph node suggests testicular cancer. Radical inguinal orchiectomy is the first-line treatment for testicular cancer, and this mass should be removed to confirm the diagnosis and assess its histology. Systemic polychemotherapy is typically reserved for more advanced cases. Scrotal orchiectomy and open testicular biopsy are not appropriate choices for initial management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a single enlarged para-aortic lymph node suggests metastasis from the testicular mass. Radical inguinal orchiectomy is the appropriate next step to both remove the primary tumor and allow pathologic staging of the disease. Systemic polychemotherapy is usually reserved for patients with advanced disease. Scrotal orchiectomy may not remove the entire tumor and open testicular biopsy is not indicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a testicular mass and an enlarged para-aortic lymph node is highly suspicious for testicular cancer with nodal metastasis. Radical inguinal orchiectomy is the gold standard for diagnosis and treatment of testicular cancer. Systemic polychemotherapy may be needed after surgery, but surgery is the first step. Scrotal orchiectomy is not recommended as it may rupture the tumor and increase the risk of spread. Open testicular biopsy is not recommended as it may cause seeding of tumor cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most appropriate next step would be a radical inguinal orchiectomy, as this allows for both diagnosis and treatment of testicular cancer. Systemic polychemotherapy would be considered after a diagnosis of testicular cancer is confirmed. Scrotal orchiectomy may not provide adequate control of lymph node spread. Open testicular biopsy is not recommended as it may cause tumor seeding and spread.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound and CT findings suggest testicular cancer with possible lymph node involvement. Radical inguinal orchiectomy is the primary treatment for testicular cancer, and further treatment will depend on the pathology of the removed specimen. Systemic polychemotherapy may be used in addition to surgery for some cases but is not the primary treatment. Scrotal orchiectomy is not recommended as it does not remove lymphatic drainage and can lead to seeding and spread of the tumor. Open testicular biopsy is not recommended as it can cause spread of the tumor and it is not necessary for diagnosis and treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound and CT findings suggest testicular cancer with lymph node involvement. The most appropriate next step in management is radical inguinal orchiectomy, which involves removing the affected testicle and spermatic cord through an incision in the groin. Systemic polychemotherapy is an option after surgical removal of the tumor, and scrotal orchiectomy is a less invasive option for non-cancerous testicular masses. Open testicular biopsy is not recommended as it may risk spreading the cancer to the scrotum.

We refer to medical textbooks for help. The presence of a single enlarged lymph node suggests that the tumor may have spread beyond the testicle, making systemic treatment necessary. An inguinal orchiectomy, which removes the affected testicle and associated structures, is the initial approach to treating testicular cancer. Scrotal orchiectomy (option B) is not appropriate because it doesn't remove lymph nodes that may require chemotherapy. Systemic polychemotherapy (option A) may be necessary following surgery, but lymph node dissection is typically performed first. Open testicular biopsy (option D) would not be the initial procedure, as it only removes a small portion of the affected tissue for diagnostic purposes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A hypoechoic, homogeneous testicular mass with sharp margins and an enlarged para-aortic lymph node are highly suggestive of testicular cancer. The most appropriate next step in management is radical inguinal orchiectomy, followed by further treatment as needed based on histopathological findings. Systemic polychemotherapy may be needed depending on the extent of the disease, but it is not the first-line treatment. Scrotal orchiectomy or open testicular biopsy are not appropriate for definitive treatment of testicular cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a testicular mass with sharp margins and an enlarged para-aortic lymph node suggests testicular cancer. The most appropriate next step in management is a radical inguinal orchiectomy, which is the surgical removal of the affected testis and adjacent lymph nodes for pathological examination. Systemic polychemotherapy is reserved for advanced cases, while scrotal orchiectomy and open testicular biopsy are inadequate for complete pathological evaluation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a testicular mass and an enlarged para-aortic lymph node strongly suggests testicular cancer. Radical inguinal orchiectomy is the standard treatment for testicular cancer, and is likely the most appropriate next step in management. A biopsy is not needed as the diagnosis is already strongly suspected based on imaging. Systemic polychemotherapy is typically given after orchiectomy for staging and treatment of any remaining cancer cells.
